sub_topic: Preparation of benzocaine from p-aminobenzoic acid and ethanol
message_1: What is the yield of benzocaine that can be obtained from the reaction of 5 grams of p-aminobenzoic acid with excess ethanol under reflux conditions for 2 hours, assuming complete reaction and isolation of the product?
message_2:
To determine the yield of benzocaine, we first need to find the theoretical yield based on the stoichiometry of the reaction and the amount of p-aminobenzoic acid used. The reaction is as follows:

p-aminobenzoic acid + ethanol â†’ benzocaine + water

First, we need to find the molar mass of p-aminobenzoic acid and benzocaine:

p-aminobenzoic acid (C7H7NO2): (7 x 12.01) + (7 x 1.01) + (1 x 14.01) + (2 x 16.00) = 137.14 g/mol
benzocaine (C9H11NO2): (9 x 12.01) + (11 x 1.01) + (1 x 14.01) + (2 x 16.00) = 165.19 g/mol

Now, we can find the moles of p-aminobenzoic acid used in the reaction:

moles of p-aminobenzoic acid = mass / molar mass = 5 g / 137.14 g/mol = 0.0364 mol

Since the reaction has a 1:1 stoichiometry, the moles of benzocaine produced will be the same as the moles of p-aminobenzoic acid used:

moles of benzocaine = 0.0364 mol

Now, we can find the theoretical mass of benzocaine produced:

mass of benzocaine = moles x molar mass = 0.0364 mol x 165.19 g/mol = 6.01 g

Assuming complete reaction and isolation of the product, the yield of benzocaine obtained from the reaction will be 6.01 grams.
